content: As of late January 2026, the OpenClaw skills system contains over 700 community abilities (skills).
ClawHub is defined as a public skill registry for OpenClaw, where all skills are explicitly free, public, open, and visible for sharing and reuse.
ClawHub's official documentation emphasizes public browsing of skills, versioned bundles, and moderation tools, without mentioning built-in monetization, licensing, or commerce features.

Any paywalling of OpenClaw skills appears to occur outside of the ClawHub registry (e.g., via private distributions, Patreon, or 'DM me for key' models) rather than as a first-class feature of ClawHub itself, as the registry is positioned as 'no gatekeeping, just signal' and skills are explicitly public and open.
ClawHub currently functions as a free, open registry hosting approximately 700+ skills, without an official paywall layer; any paywalled skills are community-run and off-platform.
ClawHub documentation describes stars, comments, tags, and search as mechanisms for skill discovery and feedback, but it does not provide a canonical 'top 10' list based on installs.
A Reddit thread indicates that download ranking is visible within the ClawHub registry, implying that some skills are measurably more popular than others.

A YouTube walkthrough suggests that skills enabling general-purpose automation, cron/heartbeat functionality, and multi-platform integration are commonly recommended within the OpenClaw/Clawdbot skills system.
A precise 'top 10 most-installed' list for ClawHub skills cannot be confirmed from publicly available material, although the existence of popularity ranking is implied.

A LocalLLaMA post describes a simulated backdoor skill created to explore supply-chain risks associated with the most-downloaded ClawdHub skill, indicating community awareness and probing of security vulnerabilities.

The threat model for OpenClaw skills is that they run locally on the user's hardware, meaning the primary risk is installing malicious code from ClawHub (acting like npm/registry) rather than remote execution on a shared SaaS.

ClawHub documentation mentions 'moderation hooks for approvals and audits,' including the ability to hide, unhide, delete, or ban skills, suggesting a reactive security and trust system for reported abusive or unsafe skills.

No major real-world security compromises (e.g., high-impact malware incidents) affecting many users are documented in the surfaced material for OpenClaw; the prominent security example is a simulated backdoor research post.

ClawHub describes skills as 'versioned bundles of files' with `SKILL.md` and metadata, referencing 'AgentSkills bundles' on its homepage and positioning itself as a registry that understands and indexes these bundles.

The surfaced documentation and marketing copy do not indicate that the underlying AgentSkills specification has been forked away from Anthropic; it is still described as an Anthropic-originated concept adopted by OpenClaw.
Herbert Yang is building multi-model agent architectures on OpenClaw, using Claude Sonnet-4 for orchestration and DeepSeek V3 for sub-agents.
Herbert Yang's work includes orchestration agents that route tasks to different models and sub-agents running cheaper or specialized models, aligning with 'council' or parallel research patterns.
Herbert Yang is heavily utilizing automation, including cron jobs and ghost jobs across restarts, within his OpenClaw deployments as part of a broader multi-agent automation setup.
When cron jobs are deleted in OpenClaw, they can persist after a gateway restart because recovery logic prioritizes orphaned `.tmp` files over `jobs.json`, leading to "ghost cron jobs."

OpenClaw's ClawHub provides discovery for skills, while the skills themselves execute locally on the user's hardware, enabling complex local compositions including chaining command-line tools and multiple models.

Common patterns in OpenClaw include an orchestrator agent (e.g., Claude Sonnet-4) coordinating sub-agents on cheaper/specialized models, cron-driven background agents for long-running workflows, and skill composition chaining shell tools, web search, and messaging channels into multi-step pipelines.
A bug in `@openclaw sessions_spawn` causes the `model` parameter to be silently ignored and fall back to a default when extra parameters like `agentId` are passed.
The `sessions_spawn` bug led a user to mistakenly believe cost optimization was working with DeepSeek V3, while everything was actually running on a more expensive default model.
To work around the `@openclaw sessions_spawn` bug, only pass the core three parameters: `model`, `label`, and `task`, omitting all other parameters, especially `agentId`.
The bug regarding `sessions_spawn` and `agentId` has been filed as GitHub issue `openclaw/openclaw/issues/6817`, but its fix status is unknown as of February 1, 2026.

The term `conversationalAI` is not a formal feature, API, or configuration field in OpenClaw's core documentation, which instead focuses on "Gateway," "multi-agent routing," "sessions," "skills," "Pi agent," and providers.
In OpenClaw, "conversational AI" appears to be a descriptive concept for community patterns like orchestrator and sub-agents in a chat-like environment, rather than an official, documented feature.
The specific phrase "superintelligent paths forward" and a canonical "superintelligence architecture" are not used in OpenClaw's reviewed documentation and public pages.

Architectures within OpenClaw that could be interpreted as "superintelligent paths" include multi-agent routing, orchestration with a higher-end model supervising cheaper models, cron-based long-running autonomous behaviors, and deep skill composition through shell commands and external APIs.
There is no formal, named "superintelligent path" pattern documented in OpenClaw; it is an aspirational framing used in some community discussions rather than an official architectural blueprint.
OpenClaw is described as an "Any OS + WhatsApp/Telegram/Discord/iMessage gateway for AI agents (Pi)" with a focus on messaging channels, multi-agent routing, and a dashboard for chat/config/sessions.
ClawHub is described as "the skill dock for sharp agents" where users can upload, version (like npm), and make AgentSkills bundles searchable with vectors, emphasizing "No gatekeeping, just signal."

OpenClaw's positioning emphasizes being messaging-first, acting as a gateway plus skills platform, with built-in multi-agent routing and a skill registry, and a strong focus on chat applications and local execution.
Brave Search API offers a "Free AI" tier with limits of 1 query/second and up to 2,000 queries/month.
OpenClaw is considered "powerful but not beginner-friendly," indicating respect for its capabilities but acknowledging a steep learning curve.
The OpenClaw ecosystem shows positive growth and community engagement with over 700 community abilities already available.
Brave Search API provides a "Base AI" tier priced at $5.00 per 1,000 requests, allowing up to 20 queries/second and 20M queries/month, with rights for use in AI applications.
The open-source / local-LLaMA community is actively engaged with OpenClaw, probing supply-chain vulnerabilities, indicating a technically critical but not dismissive sentiment.
Brave Search API offers a "Pro AI" tier at $9.00 per 1,000 requests, supporting up to 50 queries/second and unlimited queries/month, including rights for use in AI applications.

Users are encountering rough edges in OpenClaw's automation and routing, as evidenced by bug reports for cron and sessions, with a tone of frustration but also constructive debugging and issue filing.
Brave offers an "Enterprise" tier for its Search API with custom pricing and higher limits, requiring direct contact with Brave.

TrustRadius, a pricing aggregator, confirms the existence of a free version of Brave Search API and notes multiple paid plans starting around $3â€“$5 per month, categorizing them under "Data for AI" and "Data for Search."
The Brave Search API includes a free tier ("Free AI") suitable for low-volume experimentation, allowing up to 2,000 queries/month.
For OpenClaw `web_search` use, the Free AI tier is recommended for development/smoke testing, Base AI for moderate production volume, and Pro AI for high throughput or unlimited monthly queries.
Community alternatives to Brave Search API for programmatic search and SERP extraction include SerpApi (starting at $50/month), Smart Search ($399), and Listary ($19.95), as listed by TrustRadius.
OpenClaw's core focus is a messaging gateway (WhatsApp/Telegram/Discord/iMessage) combined with multi-agent routing and sessions.
ClawHub / Skills serves as a public skill registry for OpenClaw skills, offering versioned bundles and discovery/search functionalities.
Brave Search API is a programmatic search API designed for SERPs/data for AI and search applications.
OpenClaw's execution model involves a gateway on user hardware, agents via RPC (like Pi), and sessions/workspaces.
ClawHub's execution model is centralized for discovery, with skills executing locally on the user's hardware.
Brave Search API operates as a hosted web API, processing queries over HTTP.
OpenClaw's ecosystem includes over 700 community abilities, as reported in a skills video.
ClawHub lists over 700 community "abilities," all of which are public and open according to documentation.
OpenClaw is open-source under an MIT license, with no usage pricing mentioned in its documentation.
ClawHub's registry is a "free service," and all skills are public/open with no described paywall.
Brave Search API offers a Free AI tier (2,000 queries/month), Base/Pro AI paid tiers per 1,000 requests, and custom enterprise pricing.
